title: Afzelia africana
text:
Afzelia africana, the African mahogany, afzelia, lenke, lengue, apa, or doussi, is a tree <a href="species">species</a> in the family <a href="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>.
Range.
It occurs in <a href="Benin">Benin</a>, <a href="Burkina%20Faso">Burkina Faso</a>, <a href="Cameroon">Cameroon</a>, <a href="Central%20African%20Republic">Central African Republic</a>, <a href="Chad">Chad</a>, <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Congo">DRCongo</a>, <a href="Ivory%20Coast">Ivory Coast</a>, <a href="Ghana">Ghana</a>, <a href="Guinea">Guinea</a>, <a href="Guinea-Bissau">Guinea-Bissau</a>, <a href="Mali">Mali</a>, <a href="Niger">Niger</a>, <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a>, <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a>, <a href="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="Togo">Togo</a>, and <a href="Uganda">Uganda</a>. It is typically found in dense, evergreen forests, but may also be found in the <a href="savanna">savanna</a> and the coastal forests of <a href="East%20Africa">East Africa</a>.
Description.
Mature trees grow between 6 and 30 m in height. Produces white or greenish-white <a href="flower">flower</a>s with a red or pink stripe in <a href="panicle">panicle</a>s. The flowers give way to dark brown or black shiny <a href="fruit">fruit</a>s containing poisonous black <a href="seed">seed</a>s attached to an edible orange <a href="aril">aril</a>. The trunk diameter may reach 100–170 cm, sometimes more. The leaves are bright green, about 30 cm long, with 7-17 pairs of elliptic or ovate leaflets.
Uses.
"Afzelia africana" was used in the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> for <a href="ship%20building">ship building</a>. It is one of the traditional <a href="Djembe%23Shell">djembe</a> woods. The building of a reconstructed 9th-century Arab merchantman, the <a href="Jewel%20of%20Muscat">Jewel of Muscat</a>, required thirty-eight tons of "Afzelia africana" wood, which was supplied from Ghana. Curved trees were chosen for the ship's frames and timbers. The trade name for the wood of this species is doussié; it is known for being resistant to decay and <a href="termite">termite</a>s.
The leaves are sometimes used as fodder for livestock. The bark is often used for medicinal purposes in <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>, and some groups regard the tree as "a refuge of invisible spirits".
